repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure this is quite right. It's closer to `if ret_val == -1: raise` (i.e. raise whatever error is currently existing).

I don't think this quite translates into Python pseudo-code though. This feels to me like having something a little wrong could cause more confusion than it solves.

I'd actually be happier with a simplified version of the generated C code:

```
ret_val = spam();
if (ret_val == -1) goto error_label;
```

but then this pre-supposes some knowledge of C, so may not be great.

In short I don't quite know what should go here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -687,19 +687,24 @@ as a contract with the caller. Here is an example:
             @cython.cfunc
             @cython.exceptval(-1)
             def spam() -> cython.int:
-                ...
+                raise ValueError()
 
     .. group-tab:: Cython
 
         .. code-block:: cython
 
             cdef int spam() except -1:
-                ...
+                raise ValueError()
+
 
 With this declaration, whenever an exception occurs inside ``spam``, it will
 immediately return with the value ``-1``.  From the caller's side, whenever
 a call to spam returns ``-1``, the caller will assume that an exception has
-occurred and can now process or propagate it.
+occurred and can now process or propagate it. Calling ``spam()`` is roughly equivalent to::
+
+    ret_val = spam()
+    if ret_val == -1:
+        raise ValueError()

@@ -732,13 +737,18 @@ form of exception value declaration
         .. code-block:: cython
 
             cdef int spam() except? -1:
-                ...
+                raise ValueError()
 
         The ``?`` indicates that the value ``-1`` **may** signal an error.
 
 In this case, Cython generates a call to :c:func:`PyErr_Occurred` if the exception value
 is returned, to make sure it really received an exception and not just a normal
-result.
+result. Calling ``spam()`` is roughly equivalent to::
+
+    ret_val = spam()
+    if ret_val == -1:
+        if PyErr_Occurred():
+            raise ValueError()

comment_data.body:
> I'm not sure this is quite right. 

Yes these examples are simplified to express the high level logic. My ultimate goal was to do something similar to the python itertools documentation [1]. If there is consensus that this is wrong direction feel free to close this PR or just I can remove the controversial parts. I am also fine with converting it to the simplified C code. The examples are pretty simple so I think that even people not knowing C syntax will be able to extract the main point. (BTW. in my opinion any non-trivial usage of Cython requires at least basic understanding of C)


[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.accumulate

comment_data.body: Question: maybe as a small improvement we can use `error_handler` instead of `error_label` to improve readability of example. What do you think?

comment_data.body:
I think C is probably a clearer way of showing it - with Python I was just getting hung up on the idea of an unhandled exception being there without a try/catch. It just didn't write make sense to me.

I think `error_handler` is better, yes.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  enum, float or pointer type, Cython calls :c:func:`PyErr_Occurred` only when
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -824,6 +845,10 @@ Some things to note:
 
   .. note:: Pointers to functions are currently not supported by pure Python mode. (GitHub issue :issue:`4279`)
 
+* If the returning type of a ``cdef`` function with ``except *`` or ``@cython.exceptval(check=True)`` is C integer,
+  enum, float or pointer type, Cython is calling :c:func:`PyErr_Occurred` only when

@@ -750,18 +761,26 @@ There is also a third form of exception value declaration
 
             @cython.cfunc
             @cython.exceptval(check=True)
-            def spam() -> cython.int:
+            def spam() -> cython.void:
                 ...
 
     .. group-tab:: Cython
 
         .. code-block:: cython
 
-            cdef int spam() except *:
+            cdef void spam() except *:
                 ...
 
 This form causes Cython to generate a call to :c:func:`PyErr_Occurred` after
-*every* call to spam, regardless of what value it returns. If you have a
+*every* call to spam, regardless of what value it returns. Calling ``spam()`` is roughly translated to the following C code:
+
+.. code-block:: C
+
+    spam()
+    ret_val = spam();

commit.message: Docs: Improve documentation about error return values

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Docs: Improve documentation about error return values
